resources.string: Staff Portal Access: I.\tInitial assumption: As specified in Appendix B, a managerial staff decides to browse the catalogue of available manpower within the organization’s workforce. A function gets this done and the staffs are categorized based on their departments after being registered onto the system. II.\tNormal Routine: Just as described above, however, extra filtering and search features ought to be supported to quickly find specific staffs to designate tasks. III.\tWhat can go wrong: A newly recruited staffs might not show up on the system, or names and other important details might be incorrectly entered. The system should ensure that the metrics being used for searching for employees are valid such as constraints on (for example) length of ID number. IV.\tOther Activities: The manager reserves the right to register new employees to the system seeing as low-level personnel will be prevented from doing this. V.\tSystem state on completion: A selected staff’s metrics are displayed.
A sample template photo representing staff portal

Time management and work allocation are some of the most important aspects of conducting business operations or completing projects. Various investigations by previous researchers have shown that issues that manifest as a result of improper work allocation techniques and time management procedures include (but not limited to) improper actualization of tasks, noncompliance with established regulatory procedures, and lack of total identification of workforce expertise domain. This presentation discusses a proposed system that aims to adapt the characteristics of an existing time management framework in conjunction with the paradigms of work allocation into a mobile computerized system.
An image of a giant bell icon representing brief histories

Notifications: I.\tInitial assumption: Initially, the system should have notification set for any important event like confirmation of requests, errors, timestamps, deadlines, log ins and log outs, and similar actions. II.\tNormal: Same as above. III.\tWhat can go wrong: Seeing as the application will be made remotely accessible, it’s possible that the Firebase servers may encounter errors, or in the case where a device is temporarily disconnected, real time connectivity and synchronization might be impossible. Hence, the application should maintain records and return delayed notifications once connection is regained. IV.\tOther Activities: None so far. V.\tSystem state on completion: The user should have the desired set of changes pertaining to the notification available once it’s been received.
A template image showing an idealized process workflow icon

Workflow Monitoring and Goal Analysis I.\tInitial assumption: A user or manager intends to keep track of the tasks being dealt with (including goals) for a set of operations. For the monitoring procedure however, all that should be done hitherto is just as described per the namesake – advanced workflow management techniques will be touched under a different requirement that implements the ALPEN framework. II.\tNormal: A user or manager decides to highlight the list of tasks he/she has to cover, metrics will be displayed about the completion progress, and duration or elapsed time. III.\tWhat can go wrong: No tasks designated or no specific operation available. The program should cope with this by displaying an appropriate message. IV.\tOther activities: Elaborate workflow management will be handled with the ALPEN implementation to be separate requirement. V.\tSystem state on completion: The tasks are displayed as intended with the user provided utilities to return to previous or different operations.
An graphic art briefly describing the A.L.P.E.N. time management framework. A is for Activities. L for lenght, P for Plan buffer time, E for establishment of priorities, N for notation.
Manage tasks with the A.L.P.E.N. framework.
